title: Flyers salute Cup winner Timonen
text:
Latest hockey odds "I went to him at the morning skate . . . and told him we were going to give him the Cup first," Toews said. "That got the blood pumping a little bit, too. Pretty awesome memory to be able to hand that off and see him celebrate the way he did."
On Wednesday, there was another celebration for Timonen, the retired 40-year-old defenseman who spent almost half of his 16 NHL seasons with the Flyers. He was honored before the Flyers faced the Blackhawks at the Wells Fargo Center. 
As Timonen walked to center ice to drop the ceremonial first puck, he was serenaded with "Kim-mo, Kim-mo" chants from the roaring, standing crowd. 
"It gave me goose bumps," Timonen said afterward, adding that he became emotional when watching a video of former teammate Scott Hartnell, who saluted his best friend with funny, poignant remarks. Mason with team 
Goalie Steve Mason missed his second straight game because of a personal family matter, but he participated in the morning skate. Mason was unavailable to comment, but it seems likely he will return to action in the Flyers' next game, Tuesday against visiting Dallas. 
Defenseman Mark Streit said Mason "went through a very rough time. I think it's good for him to be here, be around the guys." 
Michal Neuvirth made his second straight start and Jason LaBarbera was his backup. Breakaways 
Claude Giroux played in his 500th career game Wednesday. He began the night with 451 career points. . . . .R.J. Umberger missed his second straight game with an undisclosed injury. - Sam Carchidi
